dc:description:
*CHD8* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant autism spectrum disorder in 2012 (O'Roak et al., PMID: 22495309). In addition to an increased likelihood of a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder, individuals with pathogenic variants in *CHD8* have variable degrees of intellectual disability, an overgrowth phenotype with macrocephaly and increased height, and dysmorphic facial features (PMID: 24998929). We therefore decided to curate for the generic term complex neurodevelopmental disorder.

Eight truncating variants (frameshift, nonsense) that have been reported in 8 probands in 4 publications (PMIDs: 22495309, 24998929, 26789910, 27824329) are included in this curation. Most variants are *de novo*; one individual inherited a *CHD8* variant from a heterozygous mother who has some autistic features but has not been clinically diagnosed. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points) has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity is loss of function. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by a zebrafish model and a mouse model.

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *CHD8* and autosomal dominant complex neurodevelopmental disorder. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on July 16, 2018 (SOP Version 5).

evidence.dc:description: Variant occurs in the second to last exon, however the last exon is 187 a.a. long and the variant does not occur in the last 50 bp of the penultimate exon. Absent from gnomAD.
Proband's mother also carries the variant and has autistic like features but has not been clinically evaluated. Proband's grandmother does not carry the variant and grandfather is deceased.
Default points scored for consistent phenotypes with patients.

Brain weight at E18.5 and in adulthood as well as adult brain volume were greater for heterozygous mutant mice than for wild-type mice - consistent with macrocephaly. Mutant mice had shorter intestine and tended to manifest slower intestinal transit - consistent with gastrointestinal defects in humans and zebrafish. Behavioral tests show mutant mice have increased anxiety. Both chd8 mutant mice showed lower acoustic startle response and increased PPI for 74- or 78-dB repulses before a 120-dB startle stimulus. Social contacts in social-interaction test was reduced for mutant mice, however duration per contact was greatly increases. Total duration of active contacts such as sniffing and following behavior was substantially reduced in Chd8 mutant mice compared with controls.

produced mosaic hypopigmentation phenotypes in 70% and 80% of embryos in the two clutches, respectively, and reproduced the head size defect seen with cdh8 MOs. Could not determine how many cells carried the Cas-9 induced chd8 small indels in each embryo, or if the cells were homozygous or heterozygous. Determined that head size defect was dose dependent.

evidence.dc:description: Not scored because the heterozygous model is not well phenotyped, but is said to be normal and fertile.

Chd8-/- mice die early during embryogenesis due to widespread apoptosis. The researchers found that also deleting the tumor suppressor gene p53 ameliorated the developmental arrest.  (Nishiyama et al. 2009, 15367660). Additional studies found that CHD8 may target multiple transcriptional activators for suppression of transcriptional activity through the recruitment of histone H1.
